newsitem.title: CHINA: China in $1.84 bln loan with U.S. Eximbank, Canada.
newsitem.headline: China in $1.84 bln loan with U.S. Eximbank, Canada.

text.p: China's State Development Bank signed loan agreements worth $1.84 billion with the Export Development Co of Canada and the U.S. Export-Import Bank to fund a nuclear power plant, the China Daily said on Tuesday.
The loans will be repaid in 15 years with a seven-year grace period. The loans carry an interest rate of 6.54 percent.

The money would be used to import equipment for the construction of the third phase of China's Qinshan nuclear plant in eastern Zhejiang province, about 120 km south of Shanghai, it said. The plant is a turn-key project undertaken by Canada and will be powered by two 700-megawatt heavy water reactors.
The general contractor is Atomic Energy of Canada while Bechtel Ltd of the United States and Japan's Itochu Co are the two main sub-contractors, it said.

The third phase is estimated to require about $2.86 billion in foreign exchange, to be raised by the State Development Bank, a policy bank responsible for raising funds for government infrastructure projects.
The first generator is expected to produce electricity by 2003 and the second in 2004, the newspaper said.

The first phase of Qinshan was completed in 1991 with a generating capacity of 300 megawatts, while construction of the second phase was launched in June, 1996. The second phase involves installation of two 600 megawatt generators and will be completed in 2003 with total investment of about 14.2 billion yuan ($1.71 billion).
